introduction.title: Endemic animals in Sri Lanka
introduction.description: Sri Lanka, the beautiful island nation south of India, boasts a rich biodiversity with a high percentage of endemic species. Most of these species can be found in Yala National Park and Wilpattu National Park . This means you won't find these fascinating creatures anywhere else in the world! Let's meet some of these remarkable animals:

billed_babbler.title: The orange-billed babbler
billed_babbler.description: The orange-billed babbler, also known as Ceylon rufous babbler or Sri Lankan rufous babbler, is a member of the family Leiothrichidae. The orange-billed babbler is a resident breeding bird endemic to Sri Lanka. In the past, it was considered to be a race of jungle babbler, Argya striata.

jungle_fowl.title: The Sri Lankan Jungle Fowl
jungle_fowl.description: The Sri Lankan junglefowl, also known as the Ceylon junglefowl or Lafayette's junglefowl, is a member of the Galliformes bird order which is endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is the national bird. It is closely related to the red junglefowl, the wild junglefowl from which the chicken was domesticated.

langur.title: The purple faced Langur
langur.description: This arboreal monkey, also known as the purple-faced leaf monkey, is easily recognizable by its dark face and long tail. They are social creatures living in troops and primarily found in wet zone forests.Swinging through the leafy canopy of wet zone forests, these arboreal monkeys are easily recognizable by their dark facial mask and long, prehensile tails. They live in social troops, foraging for fruits, leaves, and flowers amongst the branches.

magpie.title: Sri Lanka Blue magpie
magpie.description: This stunning bird is a must-see for any birdwatcher. With its vibrant blue plumage and long tail, it's often seen flitting through the trees in the Sinharaja rainforest and other wet zone areas. A sight to behold, this dazzling bird flits through the verdant depths of the Sinharaja rainforest and other wet zone areas. Its vibrant turquoise plumage, long tail, and inquisitive expression make it a photographer's delight.

owl.title: Serendib Scops Owl
owl.description: This recently discovered owl species is a master of camouflage, blending seamlessly into the bark of trees in the Sinharaja rainforest. Its mottled brown feathers, distinctive yellow eyes, and piercing gaze add to its captivating aura.

bullbull.title: Yellow eared Bullbull
bullbull.description: The yellow-eared bulbul is a species of songbird in the bulbul family of passerine birds. It is an endemic resident breeder in the highlands of Sri Lanka. The common name is also used as an alternate name for the yellow-throated bulbul.

hornbill.title: Sri Lanka Grey Hornbill
hornbill.description: The Sri Lanka grey hornbill is a bird in the hornbill family and a widespread and common endemic resident breeder in Sri Lanka. Hornbills are a family of tropical near-passerine birds found in the Old World.

coucal.title: Green-billed Coucal
coucal.description: The green-billed coucal is a member of the cuckoos. It is endemic to Sri Lanka's wet zone and listed as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List, as the small population declined due to forest destruction and fragmentation. It inhabits the tall rainforests of southwest Sri Lanka and nests in bushes.
